awd_titl_txt: SCC: Integrating Heterogeneous Wide-Area Networks and Advanced Data Science to Bridge the Digital Divide in Rural Emergency Preparedness and Response
awd_abstract_narration:
This Smart and Connected Communities (SCC) project will conduct innovative research in network architectures and protocols to allow emergency responders in rural areas to use TV white space, WiFi and pocket-switching for communications in areas where mobile broadband are scarce to non-existent. With this new knowledge, this project can develop and implement a framework for information exchange for emergency responders in rural communities. This scientific research contribution thus supports NSF's mission to promote the progress of science and to advance our national welfare with benefits that contribute to the safety and social and economic revitalization of rural communities. Generalizability of results is expected in relation to other rural contexts and policy domains (e.g., law enforcement and health). Research components and key results will be incorporated in existing and new undergraduate and graduate courses, demonstrating the positive impact of interdisciplinary research and promoting the core disciplines to diverse groups of students.

The goal of this project is to develop, implement, and systematically analyze a comprehensive framework and a multi-layer platform for timely information collection, integration, exchange and dissemination to support EPR in rural communities. This goal will be met through three primary activities. First, the project will develop a heterogeneous network architecture and corresponding protocols that leverage wide-area wireless backhaul over TV white spaces, WiFi and pocket-switching to provide (i) continuous communication to first responders and (ii) delay-tolerant information access to residents. In addition, the project will design a smartphone app which will support the collection of information from different sources and its exchange among first responders, government agencies and residents. Second, the mobility patterns and network availability collected will enable the development of a dynamic probabilistic community network model. Novel graph-theoretic algorithms will identify information-depleted sub-communities and inform optimal information dissemination strategies. Finally, the project will assess adoption and use of the technologies by various community members to maximize the benefits associated with timely, rich and high-quality information, disseminated through technological devices. Continuous community engagement activities for data provisioning, app design, impact co-evaluation and path to sustainability of the project are key factors for success. The framework will be co-designed and piloted in collaboration with the Town of Thurman, NY. Transferability to the broader rural context will be assessed by engaging two additional rural communities in coordination with Microsoft's Airband initiative.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project addressed the rural-urban digital divide in emergency preparedness and response. The goal was to develop and systematically analyze a comprehensive framework and a multi-layer platform for information collection, integration, exchange, and dissemination to community stakeholders including emergency agencies, first responders, local government, and residents. In pursuit of this goal we designed and refined next-generation wireless networks, relevant data science methodology, and social, organizational, and policy models for the rural setting. Our research involved a close collaboration with the Town of Thurman and the Warren County Emergency Service Department in New York State. Our transferability efforts engaged an additional town -- Johnsburg -- also in Warren County. Towards this goal, we advanced the state-of-the-art in several directions.

 

Heterogeneous wide-area networks with infrastructure mobility. Rural emergency agencies serve large areas with limited numbers of primarily volunteer staff, and without continuous mobile connectivity. This creates challenges both in staff coordination and in information exchange during emergency response. We developed the Data Mule Unit, which allows emergency vehicles to connect to community TV White Space (TVWS) networks. We used our prototype to measure TVWS network quality with mobility in our partner community. Accordingly, we designed reinforcement learning rate adaptation to ensure optimal and continuous connectivity with mobility. We further designed methodologies for continuous spectrum awareness to support spectrum sharing technologies, such as TVWS and others, in optimal spectrum reuse. 

Information integration, presentation and exchange. Emergency preparedness and response hinges on the timely dissemination of information between residents and their serving agencies -- a process that is increasingly dependent on broadband connectivity. In rural areas, several challenges hinder this process. First, residents are expected to subscribe to multiple disparate information sources split across locale (local, state and federal) and emergency type (health, fire, transportation and others). Furthermore, residents are expected to have Internet access, which is not readily available in rural areas. To address these, we developed the E!App, a smartphone-based framework for information distribution through rural socio-physical networks. The app allows users to exchange emergency information in a direct phone-to-phone fashion, obviating the need for external infrastructure. We developed peer-to-peer protocols for timely information exchange, and a reinforcement learning framework to exploit community hotspots for maximal information transfer. We deployed the E!App in our partner communities. The app integrated information about preparedness and local emergencies from 15 disparate sources including COVID-19 related notifications. It delivered timely updates to residents over the course of three years. 

Capacity and optimization of information exchange through rural socio-physical networks. Identifying subcommunities that are most deprived of information and optimizing access for them is essential to maximize the coverage of emergency preparedness and response services. To this end, we developed a suite of algorithms for community detection and their activity tracking over time which took into account temporal patterns of individual mobility and Internet access. We also proposed models for temporal scale-aware information propagation in networked contexts. The proposed algorithms and models can be employed to analyze mobility and interaction data from different rural communities and inform optimal deployment of the E!App. Our papers are currently the state-of-the-art for spatial and temporal estimation of activity in time-evolving networks with applications beyond emergency preparedness and response.

Adoption and use. The technological advancements stemming from this project were informed by the needs of rural residents and the agencies that serve them. To this end, we engaged our two partner communities in a participatory design process to identify critical information needs for emergency preparedness and response. This collaboration resulted in the co-creation of the E!App tailored to the unique challenges of rural communities, and thereby enhancing their capacity to respond effectively to emergencies. Furthermore, stakeholders' interactions with the project outcomes allowed us to study technology adoption and information use in rural contexts, implementation risks, and social, political, and economic impacts of bridging the digital divide in emergency preparedness and response. We advanced the state of understanding of human-centered design principles and co-creation processes by conducting empirical research in rural communities for developing digital tools that enhance emergency preparedness and response. 

Mentorship and training. This project trained students at all levels: from high school to PhD, at the intersection of computer, information and political science, while engaging them in meaningful and practical work with rural communities. As a result, students were trained both in fundamental methodologies as well as in field-based research and engineering. Specifically, the project trained (i) two high-school students, (ii) twenty-one undergraduate students, including four NSF Research Experience for Undergraduates Fellows, (iii) seven masters and (iv) eight doctoral students, one of whom won the UAlbany College of Nanotechnology, Science and Engineering Best Dissertation award. The project resulted in thirty one peer reviewed publications.
